utterances: You always love it when your political mentor stands right behind you 1,000 percent.
(Soundbite of laughter)
Right.
This is Dean Atchison on Dwight Eisenhower.

I doubt very much that a man whose main literary interests were in works by Mr. Zane Gray, admirable as they may be, is particularly equipped to be the chief executive of this country, particularly where Indian affairs are concerned.
(Soundbite of laughter)
That's a good one.
That's a good one.
Thank you.
Thanks very much, Leilani.
Appreciate that.

There - timing is everything, and also, where and to whom you deliver the barb is everything, but a lot of the liners in this - in this book, Chris Lamb, seem to be, well, somebody's press agent told somebody else, and that's how they get around.
Yeah.
I think that's very common, but, you know, they still make good stories.
You know, I hate that - I don't want to let the facts to get in the way of a good story.
There was a story this campaign, remember when Lynne Cheney, Vice President Cheney's wife, you know, kept telling - on an interview, kept saying how Dick Cheney was related to Barack Obama.
And they asked Barack Obama about this.
It's seven generations they were related, and they asked Barack Obama how it felt to be related to Dick Cheney, and he says, well, every family has a black sheep.
(Soundbite of laughter)

We're talking with Chris Lamb, who's the editor of ""I'll Be Sober in the Morning: Great Political Comebacks, Putdowns & Ripostes."" Of course, our Political Junkie Ken Rudin is with us, as he is every Wednesday, here at the Newseum, and you're listening to Talk of the Nation coming to you from NPR News.
Let's get Katie on the line and Katie's with us from Jackson, Mississippi.
Hello?
Hi, Katie.
You're on the air.
Go ahead, please.

Hi, well, I had one from the Democratic debates this primary season, and it was during the controversy when Barack Obama was copying some speeches from other politicians and Hillary Clinton said, that's not a change you can believe in.
That's a change you can Xerox.
That's not bad.
Yeah, I liked it.
It didn't get a good reception, but I thought it was pretty funny.
It was pretty funny, but she didn't win.
No.
(Soundbite of laughter)

Although, just for the record, though, her supporters still hope to put here in nomination at the Denver convention, and some of them are still expecting a roll-call vote that could put her over the top, over Barack Obama.

You know, we talk about - this is just changing the subject for just a moment, but how Hillary Clinton and Barack Obama made their peace in Unity, New Hampshire, but obviously, their supporters have yet to do that.
And yet, they've discovered a broad Egyptian river flowing through Denver, Colorado, denial.
Yeah, queen of denial, right.
That's right.
How can you forget - this an email from Jorie in Evanston, Illinois - how can you forget Joe Biden's, a noun, a verb and 911, describing Rudy Giuliani.
Right.
That was a pretty good line this time around.
This from Eric in Oklahoma.
Not really political but one of my favorites is that George Bernard Shaw allegedly sent two theater tickets to Winston Churchill with a note.
Here are two tickets to opening night.
Come and bring a friend, if you have one.
(Soundbite of laughter)
To which Churchill replied, cannot attend opening night.
Will come second night, if you have one.
(Soundbite of laughter)
And he also notes, I have somewhere a copy of ""The Wit and Wisdom of Spiro Agnew,"" all blank pages.
As you go through these, do you, I wonder, Chris Lamb, mark politicians are promising for future editions of this book?
I mean, are you hoping that Mike Huckabee, for example, stays on the national political stage?
Oh, yeah.
I mean, I look at politics differently from Ken does.
I'm in politics for the laughs.
Yeah, I think Huckabee will stay around.
I think McCain's, you know, McCain is pretty good.
McCain can be in future editions.
I don't know who else.
But everybody tries to, you know, run and stuff a sock in his mouth before he says something outrageous, before he does another, bomb, bomb, bomb, bomb, bomb Iran.
(Soundbite of laughter)
Yeah, I know, but I find that honest.
I mean, I would rather have a guy who's capable of being funny than someone who isn't.
Ken?
Well, I was just thinking of the other comment that John McCain said about - when it was found out that the largest export of the U.S.
to Iran is cigarettes, and he said, hopefully more of them will - more Iranians will smoke them, and more will die.
It was kind of - and so sometimes your quick wit can get you in trouble.
Mike Huckabee, when he was...
That never happened to you, did it?
(Soundbite of laughter)

No, but I don't have a quick wit - but when Mike Huckabee was at the NRA convention and they heard some loud noise in the background, I think there was some - he made some kind of a joke about a shot taken at Barack Obama in jest.
Now, the thought of that being a joke, so - but one of the reasons Mike Huckabee will not be on a Republican ticket is that tendency to speak off, you know, off-the-cuff and get yourself in trouble.
Now, let's go to David.
David's with us from Muncie in Indiana.
It's probably apocryphal, but Margaret Thatcher apparently, having dinner with her cabinet, was asked what she'd like to eat, and she said, I'll have the steak, and they said, and for the vegetables?
And she said, they will have the steak also.
(Soundbite of laughter)
That actually does, Chris Lamb, sound a lot like Margaret Thatcher.
Yes, it does.
Thanks very much for the call, David.

You know, the soundbite we played earlier, I don't think the audience understood, but when John McCain said that to Mitt Romney, yes, you are the candidate of change, it was everybody was talking about Mitt Romney's flip-flops on abortion and stem cells.
So, he said, yes, you certainly are the candidate of change.
That was where that was from.
In 1928, Ron emails us, Al Smith, the New York Sen.
or Gov., he asks, ran against Herbert Hoover for president.
A heckler yelled at Mr. Smith, tell them all you know.
It won't take long.
Mr. Smith replied, I'll tell them what we both know and it won't take any longer.
(Soundbite of laughter)
A lot of these are genuine, seemingly, ripostes to hecklers, Chris Lamb.
Yeah.
I think that's a big part of it.
You deflect an attack.
One time Lincoln was giving a speech and a man stood up and said, I can't believe I paid a quarter to see one of the ugliest men in America.
And Lincoln paused, and he said, it's true you paid a quarter to see one of the ugliest men in America, but I got that same privilege for free.
(Soundbite of laughter)
